SHORT_DESCR.P: The UK Department for International Development (DFID) is seeking to appoint a supplier to effectively manage and deliver the ‘Health Pooled Fund 3 (HPF3)’ programme in South Sudan.

The Supplier or a consortium of Suppliers will deliver all Fund Manager services for HPF3 as set out in the procurement documents to ensure the provision of essential and equitable healthcare through a network of state-run health facilities augmented with outreach activities and community level care to people in more remote areas.

The HPF3 programme is part of the Essential Services portfolio. This programme will effectively merge two current health programmes - Health Pooled Fund 2 (HPF2) which provides healthcare at health facility level and the Integrated Community Case Management 2 (ICCM2) programme which provides healthcare to children under-five within more remote communities. This will be a multi-donor programme with existing HPF2 donors expected to continue their support.

The Supplier will be expected to manage the delivery of all parts of the programme alongside providing specialist technical assistance on priority areas set out below. The Supplier will contract NGO implementing partners to deliver activities on the ground.

The programme will be implemented in eight out of the former 10 states in South Sudan, namely: Western Bahr el Ghazal, Northern Bahr el Ghazal, Unity, Lakes, Warrap, and Eastern, Central and Western Equatorias. Suppliers should propose how they would efficiently and effectively manage the delivery of health services and outreach activities to facilities and communities in the eight target states.

The supplier will be required to provide effective programme management and specialist technical assistance. The supplier will be required to manage disbursement of funds for NGO implementing partners and funds for pharmaceutical procurement collectively amounting to a value of 376 500 000 GBP (excluding procurement of vaccines, misoprostol, malaria treatments, therapeutic foods and family planning commodities which will be handled by other partners).

OPTIONS_DESCR.P: DFID will award a contract for an initial term of 60 months. The contract will include extension options of up to an additional 30 months. DFID reserves the right to scale back or discontinue this programme at any point in line with the Terms and Conditions. DFID may also scale up the programme should it prove to be having a strong impact and has the potential to yield better results.

SUITABILITY.P: Mandatory and discretionary exclusion, economic and financial standing, technical and professional ability,modern slavery act 2015 requirements, minimum insurance requirements, tenderers past performance, duty of care, international aid transparency initiative, confirmation of having signed up to the UN Global Compact, acceptance of DFID terms and conditions, and DFID statement of priorities and expectations / code of conduct, as outlined in document in the tender documentation.
A Tenderer must meet the selection criterion in relation to reliability namely that DFID must be satisfied that.
(i) the contracts on the list to be provided by the Tenderer have been satisfactorily performed in accordance with their terms or,
(ii) where that has not occurred, the reason or reasons why that has not occurred in relation to any such contract, will not recur in the performance of the contract to be awarded.
A Tenderer that fails to meet this selection criterion will not proceed further in this competition.

The contract will be governed by English Law. Prices must be quoted in GBP. All payments for the contract will be made in GBP Sterling. DFID reserves the right to annul the process at any point and not award the contract.

Legal form to be taken by the grouping of economic operators to whom the contract is to be awarded — Joint and several liabilities. DFID reserves the right to require joint ventures to form a single legal entity.
